entry.title: Custom Fields of type CodeList based on CDS Views in Analytical Apps: How to get text display option
entry.content:
Custom Fields of Type Code List based on CDS Views in Analytical Apps: How to get text display options  

Do you use a key user custom field of type “Code List based on CDS Views” in an analytical app like “Journal Entry Analyzer”? Did you ever wonder why only the code component of this custom field is shown? Do you also want to see the respective description field, as you (or other people) are not familiar with the code values? 

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. 

This blog post tells you what to do to make the description field available in analytical apps like the “Journal Entry Analyzer” app based on a concrete example.  
Please note that while we took an example from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, it's basically the same for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

Create a field of type “Code List based on CDS Views” and enable it for the analytical app  

Let’s assume you created a custom field “ZZ1_EmployeeReference” of type “Code List based on CDS Views” for business context “FINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM” (Accounting: Journal Entry Item). For your field you chose the standard SAP CDS view “I_WorkforcePerson” as value help view. To make your custom field available for the analytical app “Journal Entry Analyzer” you already enabled CDS query view “C_GLLINEITEMSQ0001”. With this, the underlying cube view “I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE” was enabled for this field as well. 

Finding the relevant CDS view

You may wonder how to figure out that you need to enable CDS view “C_GLLINEITEMSQ0001” to make the field available for the Journal Entry Analyzer app. There are several ways to find that out: 

1. Using the Custom Fields app

Within the Custom Fields app, navigate to the detail screen of your custom field. Go to the “User Interfaces” tab, select “All” and enter “Journal Entry Analyzer” in the search field on the top right of the table showing the search results. One of the results is CDS view “C_GLLINEITEMSQ0001”.  
Note: this only works in case the descriptions for the respective objects involved provided by SAP are 100% consistent – which is not always the case. 

2. Using the Fiori Apps Reference Library

You can use the Fiori Apps Reference Library as a more reliable and generic way to find out the name of the CDS view that you must enable to make the field available for the Journal Entry Analyzer app (and for any other analytical app).

Open the Fiori Apps Library and search for the app “Journal Entry Analyzer”.  You'll find this entry. Make sure to select the correct release on top of the page, which is “2025 (Private Cloud)” in our case. 

On this page, select the “IMPLEMENTATION INFORMATION” tab and then navigate to the “Configuration” section. Search for the “Bex Query” entry. The “Bex Query” entry states “2CCFIGLLITMQ0001”.  
Note: the “Bex Query” entry is only shown for analytical apps. 

When you remove the first two leading characters (“2C”), you get the name of the DDIC view (“CFIGLLITMQ0001”) belonging to the respective CDS view that is exposed in this analytical application.  
Note: In this case, the Bex Query 2CCFIGLLITMQ0001 refers to CFIGLLITMQ0001, which is a classic DDIC view. Therefore, the CDS view name differs from the view name. For view entities, the names would be the same. 

 
Fiori Apps Reference Library entry of the app “Journal Entry Analyzer” 

To derive the CDS view name from the view name, you can open the view in ADT and find the name of the CDS view in the Data Definition property of this view. 

View CFIGLLITMQ0001 

Now that you know the name of the CDS view, you can: 

  1. navigate to the detail screen of your custom field within the Custom Fields app
  2. then, navigate to the “CDS view” tab
  3. in the search field, enter the name of this CDS view. The entry for the view will be shown and you can enable it

Make the custom field visible in the analytical app 

When you have published the custom field “ZZ1_EmployeeReference”, the next step is to make it visible in the “Journal Entry Analyzer” app. To do this, open the app and populate the selection properties so that a list of entries is shown as soon as you press the “Go” button. 

In the “Available Fields” section, you'll now see the custom field “Employee Reference”. You can move it to the rows section by selecting the “Add Field to column axis” option.
As soon as you've done that, the field becomes visible as an additional row on the right side of the screen. 
Right-click on the column header of the additional row of the “Employee Reference” field and select "Display". The pop-up shows options such as  

  • “ID only” 
  • “Description only” 
  • “ID and description” 
  • “Description and ID” 

These display options allow you to show the description belonging to the code value of the “Employee Reference” field. In our case, none of these options is available (see screenshot below). 

“Employee Reference” custom field as column in analytical app: no text display options available 

How to get the text display options

To make the missing text display options available, go to the Custom Fields app and navigate to the detail screen of your custom field. In the General tab, you'll find a slider button called “Analytical Support”. Choosing this button, an addition field is displayed called “Master Data View”. Here, you can enter the master data view which is used for this field in analytical apps (like the “Journal Entry Analyzer” app). In our case, it's prefilled with “I_WorkforcePerson”, which is the same CDS view we had already chosen as value help view (see screenshot below). Note that there is also a dedicated value help view called “I_WorkforcePersonVH”, which would be even more suitable for use as “Value Help View”. 

“Employee Reference” custom field: activating Analytical Support and choosing Master Data View 

Prefilling the “Master Data View” is the default behavior of the Custom Fields app in cases where the value help view fulfills all the requirements of an analytical master data view. The view must have the header annotation “@Analytics.dataCategory: #DIMENSION”. Please note that within the value help for the “Master Data View”, only CDS views that fulfill this criterion are shown. 
Go ahead and save and publish the custom field again. Next, reload the “Journal Entry Analyzer” app. Click on the column header of the “Employee Reference” custom field to see that all of the four text display options are displayed. These allow you to configure whether and how the description should be displayed (see screenshot below). 

“Employee Reference” custom field as column in analytical app: text display options available 

With this, you are done. Congratulations! 

Technical details

In case you are interested in the technical details, let me shortly explain what you have changed by selecting a “Master Data View” for your custom field “Employee Reference”: 

Before selecting a master data view, the CDS extension that had been generated for the custom field "Employee Reference" for the cube view "I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE" underneath the query view  "C_GLLINEITEMSQ0001" looked like this: 

CDS Extend on cube view I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE before setting the “Master Data View” on the custom field 

After specifying the master data view and publishing the field again, the CDS extension looks like this: 

CDS Extend on cube view I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE after setting the “Master Data View” on the custom field 

The difference lies within the foreign key association and the respective foreign key association annotation marked in red. The analytics infrastructure needs this metadata to provide the text field.  
You may wonder how the analytics infrastructure knew which field in the “Meta Data View” I_WORKFORCEPERSON is the text field. This is derived from the annotation ObjectModel.text.element: 'PersonFullName' of the key field in “Meta Data View” I_WORKFORCEPERSON.  

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You’re cordially invited to provide them in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/). 

I want to thank Yasmina van Rooij (YasminavanRooij) and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions.

entry.title: Deep Dive: Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
entry.content:
This blog post was co-authored with @Cielo_SanabriaRuiz & @Sebastian1611 

Sustainability is no longer just about carbon emissions - it’s about understanding the full environmental impact of business operations along the value chain. With the next phase of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, the solution expands from a pure carbon tool to a broader environmental footprint platform: In addition to detailed analysis of greenhouse gas emissions – including fossil, biogenic, and removed emissions – you can now calculate and analyze your organization’s impact across a wider range of areas, such as land use , energy, waste, and resource depletion. This allows you to meet diverse reporting standards and drive operational decisions beyond decarbonization alone.

In this blog post, we’ll provide you an introduction into the topic and a guided walk-through of the implementation process for multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. You’ll see how to configure your system, manage the relevant data, and run calculations so you can unlock richer, decision-ready sustainability insights.

  • Introduction
  • Configure and Calculate Footprints for Multi-Impact Categories
  • Manage Source Data
  • Manage Footprint Settings
  • Manage Emission Factors
  • Model Footprint Parameters
  • Manage Periodic Data
  • Manage Footprint Calculations
  • Analyze Footprints
  • Communicate Footprints
  • Enhancements to APIs in Business Accelerator Hub
  • Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards

Introduction

What has changed

Since its initial release, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management has focused on calculating accurate product and corporate carbon footprints based on actual business data from SAP ERP and other sources. With the latest updates, this calculation engine now covers additional environmental impact categories so that you can monitor a wider range of environmental pressures using the same data foundation, governance model, and auditability:

Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

What multi-impact categories mean

Multi-impact categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management represent separate “lenses” on how business activities put pressure on different parts of the Earth system, all calculated on the same data foundation. This aligns well with the planetary boundaries concept, where climate change is only one boundary among several others such as biosphere integrity, land-system change, and biogeochemical flows that together define a safe operating space for humanity.

Instead of focusing on a single metric like carbon, multi‑impact categories let you translate your operational data into a set of environmental pressure indicators that mirror those planetary boundaries dimensions. In practice, this means that for every relevant activity or product, you can see not only its contribution to climate change but also how it stresses other Earth-system limits, helping you understand whether improvements in one area inadvertently push another boundary closer to its threshold.​ By structuring these indicators as configurable categories in the footprint model, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management becomes a bridge between planetary science and enterprise data, turning abstract boundary concepts into concrete KPIs based on your ERP data.

Why this matters for reporting

By going beyond carbon, you can align one consistent footprint dataset with multiple regulatory and voluntary frameworks, including emerging requirements from the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) or Science-Based Targets Initiative’s Forests, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) guidance, that increasingly demand broader environmental indicators. This reduces the need for parallel tools and spreadsheet workarounds, and helps sustainability, finance, and controlling teams work from synchronized, audit-ready numbers when preparing disclosures and customer requests.​

A structured multi-impact model also strengthens the credibility of reported data, because the same calculation logic and master data serve both internal and external views. That consistency is crucial when environmental performance becomes a criterion in financing, procurement, and customer negotiations.

Why this matters for decisions

When multi-impact indicators sit next to financial and operational KPIs, sustainability data moves from a separate reporting stream into the core of how you evaluate trade-offs and investment cases. This richer impact picture helps identify where reducing environmental pressure also boosts efficiency, resilience, and brand value, and where hidden risks accumulate if planetary boundaries are ignored.​

In this way, multi-impact categories support a shift from compliance-driven reporting to performance-driven steering, where sustainability becomes a dimension of competitiveness and innovation. These updates are a concrete step in SAP’s broader vision to transform sustainability data into a catalyst for long-term business value rather than a pure cost of doing business.

How one calculation serves many requirements

In SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, the integration and calculation setup stays exactly the same as before: You still reuse your ERP data, automate activity data collection, map to imported or pre-delivered emission factors, and run one centralized footprint calculation. The difference is that this familiar approach now delivers additional impact categories and result views, so the same activity data and methods can serve a growing list of corporate and product-level requirements without extra integration projects or parallel calculation logic.

Footprint Calculation Concept in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management

Configure and Calculate Footprints for Multi-Impact Categories

The overall workflow remains similar to a standard carbon footprint calculation, but with crucial distinctions in steps where you specify and assign your desired impact categories and their corresponding factors:

  • Manage Source Data: Prepare foundational data.
  • Manage Footprint Settings: Configure how footprints are calculated, including impact categories.
  • Manage Emission Factors: Define impact factors for all chosen categories and link them to purchased products.
  • Model Footprint Parameters: Refine specific calculation models (e.g., energy flow, allocations).
  • Manage Periodic Data: Input business transactional data for the calculation period.
  • Manage Footprint Calculations: Execute the footprint calculation across all selected impact categories.
  • Analyze Footprints: Review and analyze on the multi-category results on different aggregation levels.
  • Communicate Footprints: Send your calculated environmental footprints to other applications.

 

Manage Source Data

The foundational master data required for environmental impact calculations is uploaded using the Import Master Data application. There are no changes to this app, for details see: Import Master Data.

 

Manage Footprint Settings

To tailor the calculation process, select your desired configuration variant using the Manage Calculation Variants app. You can either opt for the DEFAULT variant or configure a new one. Calculation variants define various parameters, such as allocation rules and Scope 2 calculation methods, which are fundamental to the overall footprint calculation. It is important to understand how these settings influence the results across all selected impact categories to ensure consistency and accuracy. See Manage Calculation Variants for more information.

Next, go to the Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes app to define the boundaries and specific impact categories to be assessed in your environmental footprint calculation. This is a critical step when expanding beyond pure product carbon footprints (PCFs) and corporate carbon footprints (CCFs). When creating a footprint inventory scope, you can select up to ten impact categories for a single scope, including Climate Change which is always mandatory. If you enable the Accept Missing Emission Factors attribute for an impact category, any entities lacking an emission factor for that category will be excluded from its specific calculation. This attribute can be enabled for each impact category individually. For details, see Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes.

Manage Inventory Scope

 

Manage Emission Factors

To calculate footprints for your desired Impact Categories, you must provide corresponding emission and/or impact factors. SAP Sustainability Footprint Management allows you to utilize pre-delivered emission factor data packages, or you can import your own data via the Manage Emission Factors app. This is a key area where the process expands significantly when moving beyond a single CO2e factor. The key considerations for managing emission factors for multiple impact categories are the following:

  • For each impact category you wish to assess, a specific impact factor is required. Therefore, when populating either the LCA or Simple Template, you must input a separate entry for each impact category. Although these factors might relate to the same product, energy source, or business activity, they are differentiated by their distinct Impact Category ID.
  • Impact factors other than Climate Change (CLCH) must be added via Data Packages and cannot be manually inserted into the Emission Factor Periods in consuming apps such as Model Energy Flows, Manage Waste Footprints, or Manage Business Activities.
  • For importing emission factors, both the simple template (version 3) and the LCA template (version 5) in the Manage Emission Factors app have been enhanced to support multiple impact categories.

For details on maintaining emission factors data in the templates, see Emission Factors Data. Under Impact Categories, you find a table with all impact categories, including their IDs, dimensions, and indicators.

Manage Emission Factors

After importing the relevant emission factors, you can move to the Manage Purchased Product Footprints app to map your imported products from your ERP system to the previously maintained emission factor datasets. Those must include data for the Climate Change impact category and can optionally include emission data for additional ones. The mapping can be done manually or AI-assisted – with just one mapping, all available data for the impact categories is linked automatically. Clicking on a mapped dataset, provides you with an overview of all mapped content. See Manage Purchased Product Footprints for more information.

Manage Purchased Product Footprints

Similar to purchased products, the Manage Waste Footprints app enables you to manage the values used to calculate Climate Change and other environmental impacts resulting from the treatment of a specific type of waste within a defined period. Those can also be entered manually or mapped to maintained emission factor datasets. For more details, see Manage Waste Footprints.

Finally, Business Activities allow you to calculate environmental impacts based on form-based data collection. In the Manage Business Activities app, you can create those business activities and map the corresponding emission factor. For each business activity, you can determine which GHG scope the activity relates to. Find all details under Manage Business Activities.

 

Model Footprint Parameters

When calculating impacts for energy-related and transport activities, the Manage Locations app allows you to manage relevant locations. Ensure all locations pertinent to your chosen impact categories are added. See Manage Locations for more information.

The Model Energy Flows application is crucial for managing energy consumption and its associated impacts. When creating Energy Sources and their corresponding emission factor periods, you can now connect to emission factor datasets that include impact categories beyond just Climate Change. This means that the environmental impact of energy consumption, whether from electricity, fuel, or other sources, can now be assessed not only for its carbon footprint but also for its contribution to abiotic resource depletion or other selected impact categories, provided the relevant emission factors are assigned. While you can create a full energy flow model, including meter readings to allocate energy and emissions to locations, resources and manufactured products, you may also opt to create only the relevant Energy Sources required for your Corporate Carbon Footprint calculations. In both cases, the periodic consumption values, and if enabled the corresponding meter readings, are entered later in a GHG Data Form via the Record GHG Data app. For more information, see Model Energy Flows.

Manage Energy Source

For distributing environmental impacts from senders (e.g., Business Activities, Facilities, or Waste Types) to receivers (e.g., Facilities, Process Infrastructures, or Products), you can define Allocation Schemes and Allocation Rules in the Manage Allocations app. A sender is selected and linked to one or multiple receivers. The allocation ratio determines which portion of the sender’s total impact (across all calculated impact categories) is allocated to each receiver. This ensures that the environmental impacts associated with, for example, a shared energy source are correctly attributed to the products or processes consuming that energy. Check Manage Allocations for all details.

 

Manage Periodic Data

To calculate environmental impacts related to purchased goods and services, business transactions need to be imported from your ERP system via the Import Business Transactions app. This includes data related to the movement of physical goods that are relevant for calculating product and corporate environmental impacts. Typical goods movement transactions that track the flow of products are: Opening Stock, Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Transfer, Goods Issue and Receipt from Production, and Internal Service Confirmation. Periodic data will be imported within the periodic boundaries defined in the Footprint Inventory Scope. These transactions form the basis for actual activity data that will be multiplied by the impact factors across all selected impact categories. Find more information under Import Business Transactions.

For capturing activity data for Energy Consumption, Meter Readings, Business Activities, and Waste Generated in Operations, the Manage GHG Data Collection and Record GHG Data applications offer a form-based data collection approach. You can enter activity values for each footprint inventory scope and period within these apps. While the apps are named with GHG, they now support the collection of activity data that will be linked to emission factors for all selected impact categories, not just greenhouse gases. For all details, see Manage GHG Data Collections and Record GHG Data.

GHG Data Collection

 

Manage Footprint Calculations

Once all data is set up and provided in the preceding steps, the organizational environmental impact for the selected impact categories can be calculated. In the Calculate Footprints app, maintain the necessary data, such as the Footprint Inventory Scope, Calculation Variant, and Period. Before initiating the calculation, it’s crucial to check for data completeness to ensure accurate results across all chosen impact categories. The calculation engine will then process all assigned impact factors against the activity data. For more information, see Calculate Footprints.

To view the detailed results per impact category, navigate to the Manage Footprint Results app or click Show Results directly within the Calculate Footprints app. You can then click on each calculated Footprint Item within the inventory to drill down into details. While the Sankey chart currently remains focused on Climate Change, the Footprint Information section now clearly displays the calculated impact categories per GHG scope (where applicable), along with the corresponding total footprint and footprint per unit for each impact category you selected. See Manage Footprint Results for details.

Manage Footprint Results

 

Analyze Footprints

For analyzing the calculated footprints, the Footprint Overview app provides a high-level summary of your impact calculation results. While the initial general overview and dashboards emphasize the Climate Change impact category, clicking on the respective dashboards allows you to navigate to more detailed analyses. See Using the Footprint Overview Application for more information.

The Corporate Balance app provides a consolidated view of your organization’s environmental performance. While it may not yet offer specific multi-impact-category features distinct from the Climate Change balance, it serves as an overarching summary. For learning more about viewing organizational upstream and downstream emissions, see Using the Corporate Balance Application.

The Purchased Products analytics app now allows you to display calculated footprints by impact category via a filter option. This enables a detailed understanding of the environmental burden associated with specific procured products across all selected impact categories, providing a richer perspective than just CO2e. For more information, see Using the Purchased Products Application.

Purchased Product Footprints Analytics

Similarly, the Sold Products analytics app offers a filter option to display the calculated footprints by impact category. This is crucial for understanding the cradle-to-gate (or other defined boundary) impacts of products your organization sells, reported across various environmental indicators. Find more details under Using the Sold Products Application.

The Energy Consumers analytics app has been enhanced to allow you to choose and display the calculated footprints by impact category through a filter option. This provides granular insights into the environmental impacts (e.g., Climate Change, Resource Depletion) associated with energy consumption for specific entities within your organization. See Using the Energy Consumers Application to learn more.

Finally, also the Waste Generated in Operations analytics app now includes a filter option, enabling you to display the calculated footprints by impact category. This allows for a comprehensive assessment of the environmental burden from internal waste management across different environmental dimensions. Find more information here: Using the Waste Generated in Operations Application.

 

Communicate Footprints

For Communicating Footprints you can use different apps to perform the configurations required to make calculated footprints available to be consumed by other systems, for example, SAP Sustainability Control Tower and SAP Cloud ERP:

The Manage Footprint Communication app allows you to configure which footprint data be shared with other systems like SAP Sustainability Control Tower. Currently, it focuses on climate change results.

With the Publish Product Footprints (internal) app, you can publish calculated Product Carbon Footprints (PCFs) to connected SAP Cloud ERP systems for business process integration.

For supply chain collaboration, you can use the Publish Product Footprints (Carbon Data Exchange) app to publish PCFs externally to customers and partners leveraging the standardized PACT format.

 

Enhancements to APIs in Business Accelerator Hub

Updates have also been made to existing APIs on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub to support the expanded impact category capabilities, now also supporting all categories in addition to Climate Change:

  • Item Footprints
  • Emission Factors

 

Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards

To facilitate external reporting, especially for frameworks that require specific categorization of impacts, you can map your calculated impact category results to relevant reporting categories. The following figure illustrates how certain Climate Change sub-impact categories serve as building blocks to support different key reporting standards:

Impact Categories as Building Blocks for Key Reporting Standards

We plan to publish additional blog posts in the future to explain in detail how the mapping of calculated impact categories to the listed standard’s reporting categories works – stay tuned!

For general news on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: Invoice Submission to the Singapore Tax Authority: How to Automate Invoice Note Filling in XML Files
entry.content:
Are you a GST-registered business in Singapore subject to the GST InvoiceNow Requirement? If so, you need to submit invoice data electronically to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS). This may include providing invoice notes in XML files submitted to IRAS. This blog provides guidance on how you can automate this step.

A few quick notes:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is the solution to support GST InvoiceNow requirements. For an overview, check out this blog: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Singapore GST InvoiceNow.
  • This blog applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, SAP S/4HANA, and SAP ERP.
  • This blog quotes information from some IRAS guidelines. The quoted information is accurate as of the publication date of the blog. As these IRAS guidelines are subject to change, we recommend checking the latest versions for the most current information.

 

What Is an Invoice Note?

Here’s the definition of invoice note from TX2 - Annex - Data Specifications, which can be downloaded from here:

A textual note that gives unstructured information that is relevant to the Invoice as a whole such as the reason for any correction or assignment note in case the invoice has been factored.

An invoice note is displayed in one of these XML elements, depending on the invoice type:

  • ubl:Invoice / cbc:Note for invoices
  • ubl:CreditNote / cbc:Note for credit notes

IRAS specifies the scenarios where an invoice note is mandatory, such as credit notes and self-billing invoices. For certain special scenarios, IRAS prescribes their note texts. For example, according to the e-Tax Guide “Adopting GST InvoiceNow Requirement for GST-registered Businesses (First Edition)”, you must include this exact note text in self-billing invoices:

The invoice is a Buyer Created Tax Invoice. The tax shown is your output tax due to the Comptroller of GST.

 

The Challenge: Automating Beyond the Standard

To include an invoice note in a submitted XML file, you need to enter the note text in a specific source document field. For those scenarios that require specific note texts, it would be a great time-saver if the system can fill in them automatically. The standard solution already does this for these scenarios:

  • Self-billing invoices
  • Customer invoices with the GST category code SRCA-S (Customer accounting supply made by supplier)
  • Supplier invoices with the GST category code TXCA (Standard-rated purchases of prescribed goods subject to customer accounting)

What about other scenarios? Manually entering invoice notes is really time-consuming and prone to error.

 

The Solution: BAdI to the Rescue

You can define your own logic for populating invoice notes using the following Business Add-Ins (BAdIs):

ProductBAdI
  • SAP S/4HANA
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • SAP ERP
EDOC_ADAPTOR: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionEDOC_ADAPTOR_Cloud: SET_OUTPUT_DATA method

In this blog, we'll show you how to create a BAdI implementation that populates invoice notes for customer invoices (eDocument type: SGC5C_INV) in these scenarios based on the tax code:

ScenarioInvoice Note Text Prescribed by IRASTax Code You Use
Gross Margin SchemeThe transaction is under the Gross Margin Scheme.S1
Approved Marine Fuel Trader SchemeThe Payment of GST is not required under the AMFT Scheme.Z1
Discounted Sale Price SchemeThe transaction is under the Discounted Sale Price Scheme.Z2

 

Step-by-Step Guide: Sample BAdI Implementation in SAP S/4HANA, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP ERP

Step 1: Create a customer package.

Some objects are created when you create a BAdI implementation. To transport these objects across a customer landscape, create a customer package or choose an existing customer package.

Step 2: Create an enhancement implementation.

In this example, we create an implementation named ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 by doing the following:

  1. Call up the SE19 transaction.
  2. Select the New BAdI radio button in the Create Implementation section and enter ES_EDOCUMENT in the Enhancement Spot field. Choose Create.



  3. Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the enhancement implementation name and Implementation: eDocument Adaptor Singapore as the short text. Choose Continue.



    When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.

  4. In the window that appears next, do the following:
    • Enter ZEI_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the BAdI implementation name.
    • Enter ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 as the implementation class.
    • Select the BAdI definition EDOC_ADAPTOR.

  5. Choose Continue. When prompted for a package, enter the package created or chosen in step 1.
  6. Activate your changes.
  7. Expand the tree for the BAdI implementation you just created. Double-click Filter Values.



  8. In the filter values details on the right, choose Create Filter Combination. 



  9. In the Choose Filter dialog, select COUNTRY. Choose Continue.
  10. Double-click the COUNTRY filter.
  11. In the Display Filter Value dialog, enter SG as Value 1 and select = as Comparator 1. Choose Continue.



    The filter combination you just created looks like this: 



Step 3: Update the ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5 class.

  1. Call up the SE24 transaction.
  2. Enter the object type ZCL_EDOC_ADAPTOR_SG_C5. Choose Change.



  3. Double-click the method IF_EDOC_ADAPTOR~SET_OUTPUT_DATA.



  4. Add the sample code below into this method:
        FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_mwskz> TYPE mwskz,
                       <fs_tax_data_tab> TYPE any,
                       <fs_tax_data> TYPE any.

entry.title: Resolve Overprotection
entry.content:
Resolve Overprotection

Customers easily understand the benefits of supply protection. Protecting quantities for specific customers, regions, or any defined group is a common use case in shortage situations (to learn more about supply protection check the blog titled Supply Protection in a Nutshell). 

However, protecting too much can run into the issue known as overprotection. 

S/4HANA 2025 offers a solution to identify and mitigate overprotection. 

What is Overprotection?

Every requirement, such as a sales order, must adhere to the restrictions defined by supply protection. If there is stock available but not every request receive confirmation due to supply protection, this situation is referred to as overprotection. 

The following illustration helps to understand the definition of overprotection. 


Illustration 1: Overprotection

On the left side of the illustration, a blue bar shows the available stock or supply. Colored boxes indicate the defined remaining protection for France (purple), Italy (green) and Germany (orange). Grey boxes represent the restrictions from the perspective of the related supply protection objects. In this example, the horizontal red line represents the available stock. For a demand matching the supply protection object for Germany, the grey boxes for Italy (3000) and France (4500) are to be considered as restrictions. Therefore, even a demand matching the priority 1 protection group for Germany doesn’t receive confirmation. All other potential demands also exceed the red line. This means, in all cases, the restrictions surpass availability. 

Other critical Situations


Illustration 2: Blocked SUP Objects

Assuming the stock is slightly higher, there won’t be overprotection. Demands that match the priority 1 protection for SUP Germany could receive confirmation. However, even this situation might still be considered as critical because complete markets, such as France and Italy, are blocked. In some cases, it might be acceptable that complete supply protection objects are blocked, but, in other situations, this is likely unintended and treated as a critical problem. 

If there is more supply (illustration 3), supply protection works as intended – some demands are blocked, and only high-prioritized demands receive confirmation. Depending on the situation, this can also be seen as critical, especially if the planned protection is defined with the setting Restriction outside planned Protection. It’s obvious that other demands (not matching a protection) won’t receive confirmation. 


Illustration 3: Blocked SUP Groups

Identify Overprotection and other critical Situations

Overprotection was considered as issue because it was difficult to identify. It doesn’t appear in any app that shows availability. Within a sales order, users can see that supply protection prevents order confirmation. However, they can’t see that all other orders for the same material-plant-combination are also blocked. 

Overprotection can occur at the Restricted Product level. A restricted product is the combination of a plant-material and the defined planning level, such as plant/storage location, plant/segment, or plant/batch, for which supply protection is defined and active. 

Since supply protection is only a virtual restriction, depending on the context, the system didn’t indicate critical situations involving blocked supply protection objects.  

This has changed with the new Resolve Overprotection app which displays overprotection and other critical situations. Additionally, users can use Situation Management to receive alerts.  

Alerting for Overprotection

Customers can use the situation template CA_ATP_SUP_OVERPROTECTION to customize alerts based on their needs. Users can choose whether to receive alerts for overprotection situations or for other critical situations. Situation Management offers various settings for alert recipients, technology, and relevant criteria. 

App Resolve Overprotection

The Resolve Overprotection app provides users with a quick overview of the restricted products. By default, it sorts these restricted products on the criticality of the check result status. 


Illustration 4: The "Resolve Overprotection" App


Illustration 5: “Resolve Overprotection” Result List

Users can view the planning level of the restricted product, the check result status, and the number of blocked supply protection objects and blocked supply protection groups.  

They can also navigate to the details of a restricted product. Here, users can see if and how much available quantity is accessible for each related protection group.


Illustration 6: Restricted Product Details View

Mitigate Overprotection

Starting from the overprotection details, users can navigate to the individual supply protection objects. They can adjust the protected quantities to improve the situation. Returning to the details page of the restricted product displays the updated check result status after retrieving the updated data using the Refresh button. 

As an alternative, you can also switch to edit mode by clicking the Edit button to simulate different mitigation options. Three different options are displayed: 

  • Prioritized reduction 
    The planned protection of all time buckets is reduced by a certain percentage. Protection groups with high priority get a low percentage reduction, while protection groups with low priority will get a high percentage reduction. 
  • Zero protection for the lowest priority 
    Only the protected quantities of the protection group with the lowest priority for each supply protection object are reduced. The reduction is 100%, completely removing the restriction by this group. 
  • Reduced Restriction Quantity by Percentage 
    The protected quantity of all related time buckets is reduced by the same percentage. 

Users can simulate the different options and decide whether to save the changes or choose another mitigation strategy. The app provides information if there is a positive available quantity accessible for the individual protection groups. There isn’t a clear recommendation for the best mitigation strategy. Users can apply the same or a different mitigation strategy after the initial one. 


Illustration 7: Mitigate Overprotection

“Overprotection” not Addressed by the App

The Resolve Overprotection app identifies situations where supply protection restrictions exceed the available stock or supply. However, some lock issues won’t be identified as overprotection. 

For example: Suppose there is protection for one or more groups that could use the protection because there is unrestricted stock. However, matching demands are blocked by other restrictions, such as a credit block or a fully consumed product allocation (PAL) bucket. In this case, these blocked groups can’t use the defined protection, and other demands from other groups are also blocked by this non-consumable restriction. This issue arises from the setup of protection combined with the setup of product allocation.   

Summary

With the Resolve Overprotection app, along with its alerting feature, makes it easy to identify issues like overprotection and other critical situations. You can also easily mitigate the issues and overcome mutual blocking caused by supply protection. 

Nevertheless, it is crucial to set up supply protection correctly and protect only minimum quantities. There are best practices available to avoid overprotection already at an early stage. 

The setup of Supply Protection (SUP) together with Product Allocation (PAL) should be done with care. It’s recommended to use similar characteristics when defining groups in SUP and PAL. In PAL, you typically define a maximum quantity while supply protection represents minimum quantities. The interplay of both methods works best when there’s a corridor between these quantities.  

Video: Resolve Overprotection

entry.title: Clean Core maturity and the new Extensibility Levels
entry.content:
For years, the architectural conversation around SAP S/4HANA seemed trapped in a rigid side.
On one side, the purist vision moving all development to side-by-side extensibility on SAP BTP. On the other side, the operational reality, where complex transactional logic and proximity to data made decoupling code technically expensive and sometimes unfeasible..

However, we often lost in this conversation: Clean Core... what's side-by-side... what's On-stack
Not so far back in time, we followed the 3-Tier Development Model. This framework tried to organize development into three tiers (Tier 1 for Cloud, Tier 2 with Wrappers, Tier 3 for Legacy).

While useful, there's a new pragmatic second generation framework: the Clean Core Level Concept
This new maturity model increases the availability of APIs and reduces the forced need for wrappers, incorporating classic ABAP use cases safely. But how does this translate into the modern architecture of Levels A, B, C, and D?

Level A: The Gold Standard (On-stack & Side-by-side)
Level A doesn't force you off-stack. It represents extensions that rely exclusively on stable, public interfaces backed by stability. Is agnostic to the deployment environment:

Side-by-side Extensions: Decoupled extensions running on the Business Technology Platform. This ecosystem allows for SAP Build (low-code/pro-code), CAP (Java/Node.js), and ABAP Cloud (Steampunk) to create scalable apps and automations

On-stack Extensions: Created inside SAP S/4HANA Cloud (either as Key User Extensions or Developer Extensions). This validates that building tightly coupled logic within the S/4HANA it's ok, provided that released technologies like RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming) and CDS Views are used. So that by using of released APIs and strict syntax checks, you can build tightly coupled logic (essential for transactional integrity) without creating technical debt

Level B: The Pragmatism of "Classic APIs"
Unlike Level A, which relies on stability contracts, Level B uses Classic APIs and frameworks. While not strictly "Cloud" capable, these are upgrade-stable.
You can identify these in the Cloudification Repository. Object frameworks such as SAPscript, and ALE/IDoc integrations fall into this category. This provides a critical "safe harbor," allowing to leverage proven legacy technologies without facing immediate refactoring pressure

Level C: Risk Management and Changelogs
When business reality demands the use of internal SAP objects for legacy scenarios, we enter Level C. Unlike the previous levels, there is an upgrade risk here. To mitigate it, SAP provides the Changelog for SAP Objects, a tool that allows you to identify incompatible changes early and plan proactive actions. Although not the preferred approach, it is a valid option if managed with wrappers to isolate the dependency.

Level D : The red line (Technical Debt)
Any extension that uses non-recommended patterns, such as direct modifications to the standard, direct writing to tables, or Implicit Enhancements, falls into this category. This represents the highest risk of technical debt and must be rigorously blocked using ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) checks. These patterns bypass standard logic and guarantee disruption during upgrades

Extensions objects are classified as unfit for customer use (marked as "noAPI" in the Cloudification Repository) 

By understanding Levels (A, B, C, D) we can make architectural decisions that balance technical purity with operational reality, prioritizing business stability and flexibility.... But Important!!: Beyond the levels, a Clean Core strategy requires governance. The fundamental principle is: Extensions must be avoided when possible. Before, we must to evaluate if standard functionality covers the process. If the extension is inevitable, we must ensure that extensions don't break Upgrades
To decide between an On-stack or Side-by-side implementation, customers should use the SAP Application Extension Methodology. This methodology helps to define a custom extension strategy. It addresses challenges like "clean core" by offering a structured, standard approach. This ensures a common understanding and terminology and it allows to assess technical options and make informed decisions to build an extension framework for your organization.

entry.title: Joule Capability Documentation Chat
entry.content:
As use cases involving AI become increasingly intertwined with our lives, we have developed a documentation chat for ABAP developers. The documentation chat is available for you to ask questions and find solutions to any ABAP development problem you may have. The conversation with the documentation chat should help you solve your tasks and serve as your helpful guide.

In this blog, we explain the rationale behind the documentation chat, how to use it, and what it offers in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511.

 

Rationale

Our primary goal is to provide easy access to the ABAP Cloud product documentation and to enhance the accessibility and findability of our content. Finding documentation has always been an issue that’s often caused by missing semantics in the provided content. To address this issue, we employ retrieval-augmented generation to deliver relevant information in response to a query.

 

Using the Documentation Chat

The documentation chat is available as a Joule capability in ABAP development tools for Eclipse. For information about using Joule in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, refer to Opening the Joule Chat View.

To use the documentation chat, follow these steps:

  1. In the Joule view, select the button /.
  2. Choose docs.

    If you send the request without a prompt, you receive a description of the capability.
  3. Enter your question in the text area.

     



  4. Press Enter or select the Select message (Enter) button.

    You receive a response to your question. The answer can include text, bullet points, and code examples. Also, references are always provided, allowing you to view the source documentation and verify the given answer.

 

Supported Documentation

As of SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511, the documentation chat includes the following documentation:

  • ABAP Keyword Documentation
  • ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model
  • ABAP Data Models
  • ABAP Cloud

When chatting with the documentation, you can expect assistance with the topics in the documentation above. It is also possible to ask follow-up questions after an initial question, as the chat history is respected.

In the coming releases, you can expect more to come. Feel free to leave a comment or a like.

entry.title: Through the Looking Glass: S/4 HANA Service Management: Financial Attributes Assignment Block
entry.content:
Here is another blog from my 'Through the Looking Glass' series. This time I take a look into the upcoming  "S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition" release 2025, feature package 1. A new assignment block is available for service transaction items using item-based accounting, which means service contract items and service order items of several types.

The assignment block gives you answers to four questions:

1.) Is this item settled, and if yes, how is it settled?

2.) Is Event-Based Revenue Recognition used for this item; and if yes, which revenue recognition key?

3.) Which financial reporting attributes does my item have?

4.) Is my item part of a financial hierarchy? And which part is it?

Let's start with the first part about settlement.

In the latest releases settlement was introduced for item-based accounting. This section now gives you more detailed information about how settlement is handled. The following options are possible:

No Settlement: (N) No settlement is allowed.

Standalone Settlement (S): If you settle, only postings from this item are taken.

Hierarchy Settlement – Root (H): The item is the root of a hierarchy. If settlement is done, all child hierarchy items are settled together with the root item. This can be the case for financial hierarchies or execution order items with follow-up maintenance orders.

Hierarchy Settlement – Child (C): The child of a root hierarchy as mentioned above. It is settled with and by the root item.

Standalone Settlement (Existing) (empty value) Same as S but the upgrade case, meaning the item was created before settlement with this indicator was defined.

Hierarchy Settlement – Child and Parent (O): The item is both a child and parent in a financial hierarchy together, like an execution order item in a financial hierarchy. It is settled together with the child to the root object.

Additionally, the used settlement profile is displayed.

Now let's check out the Event-Based Revenue Recognition area.

Event-Based Revenue Recognition uses specific revenue recognition keys assigned to the item category, which define the revenue recognition method used for the item.

Examples are the percentage of completion method (PoC), the completed contract method, and others.

Which methods can be used for service items can be found here.

Methods usable for the execution order process are described here.

So, now you can see what method is applied to the respective item.

The third area is about Financial Reporting Attributes.

The section Financial Reporting displays core data for reporting:

  • Business Area
  • Costing Sheet
  • Costing Variant
  • Functional Area
  • Profit Center.

The last area is only displayed if the item is part of a financial hierarchy, meaning it is assigned to a service contract item category with the setting “Root Item in Financial Hierarchy”.  The predecessor service contract and the service contract item number of the root item are displayed.

This concludes our excursion of the assignment block, which many customers requested.

entry.title: Generate Client Certificate for Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities via SAP BTP
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

  1. Access to the relevant subaccount in which you want to generate a certificate.
  2.  Admin privileges for the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition system.

Generate Client Certificate 

  1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Connectivity ➡️ Destination Certificates ➡️ click on Create
  2. Under the Generation Method section, choose External service

  3. Under the Generation Details, fill in the following fields:
    1. Name – The name you would like to assign to the certificate.
    2. File Extension – Leave this field as is, with the value PEM.
    3. Validity – Select the desired duration; I chose one year.
    4. Password – Although this field is optional, it is required to complete the installation in the system.
    5. Automatic Renewal – Set according to your preference; the default value is "On".
  4.  Click on Create.
  5. You will get the following screen:

Download the Client Certificate 

To download the certificate we generated along with its private key, we’ll need to use the Destination Service (Cloud Foundry) API.
The full certificate isn’t available for download through the SAP BTP admin console.
 
You can find the full API documentation on: https://api.sap.com/api/SAP_CP_CF_Connectivity_Destination/overview 

The API URL is: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.<your_region>.hana.ondemand.com/destination configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates
 
In my example, the region is eu10.
 

For authentication, we need to create an instance of the Destination Service and generate a service key if one does not already exist in our subaccount.

  1. Create a Destension service instance for the authentication details:
    1. In your SAP BTP Subaccount, navigate to Services ➡️ Instances and Subscription ➡️ click on Create.
    2.  Choose the "Destination Service" service, select the "lite" plan, and use a space you have authorization to create an instance in ➡️ click on Create.
    3. After creation, you will see a new instance 
    4. Create a new service key, enter the Service Key Name ➡️ Create.
       

    5. Click on ... ➡️ View
       
The authentication method required for this API is Bearer token authentication.
In my example, I use the Postman client, but you can also work with any other API tool that supports OAuth 2.0 authentication.
 
For the authentication with OAuth 2.0, enter the following fields (when using Pastman):
  1. Grant Type = "Client Credentials" 
  2. Access Token URL = "url" in our service key JSON file with the prefix "/oauth/token"
  3. Client ID = "clientid" in our service key JSON file.
  4. Client Secret = "clientsecret" in our service key JSON file.
  5. Client Authentication = "Send as Basic Auth header".
  6. Click on Get New Access Token ➡️ on the new pop-up window click on Use Token

After we have a token, we can call the API to get our certificate:

The method is GET, and the URL will be https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/{Your Certificate Name}.

In my example, the URL will be: https://destination-configuration.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/destination-configuration/v1/subaccountCertificates/J4D_Guide.pem.

The response for the call needs to be like:   

We will get the full certificate, including the private key in base64, and now we need to convert it to text and save it as a PEM certificate.

 
For the conversion, I'm using the terminal on my computer with the command:
echo "base64string" | base64 --decode​

You will need to replace the "base64string" with your certificate in base64.

The decoded result will be like the example below:

I copied the full result to a text editor and saved it with the PEM extension. 

Load the Client Certificate to the SAP S/4HANA private cloud 

After we have the PEM certificate with the private key, we can proceed and load the certificate to the ABAP system.

  1. Enter the "STRUST" transaction ➡️ on the top toolbar, and click on "Environment" ➡️ and choose "SSL Client Identities of System "

     

  2.  ➡️ Click on the change button. 
  3. Click on "New Entries" ➡️ Enter an Identity and Desctiption ➡️ Click Enter ➡️ Click on Save.
  4. You will need a transport request to save the changes, so create a new one.
  5. The new entry will appear on the left panel
  6. If you are in display mode, click on the change button. once again.
  7. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ➡️  Import ➡️ PKCS#8/PEM 
  8. In the file browser, choose the file you created in the previous step.
  9. Enter the certification password as entered in the SAP BTP admin portal.
  10. You will see the certificate details:
  11. Click on the check mark to proceed to the next step.
  12. On the top toolbar, click on PSE ➡️ ➡️ Save As...
  13. On the pop-up, choose the SSL Client with the client we created before ➡️ Click on the check mark

We’re done 😊

entry.title: Use Custom Roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Introduction: With the increasing adoption of Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition (PCE), customers are now looking beyond standard business roles and want to control access using custom roles. This becomes especially important when Joule is enabled for selective users, specific business scenarios, or restricted transactional access.

However, configuring custom roles for Joule is not entirely straightforward. It requires a clear understanding of role content, content exposure, and identity provisioning, all of which must work together to ensure Joule can access the required business data and applications.

In this blog, I will walk you through three key topics that will help you successfully use custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA PCE:

1️. What a Custom Role Must Contain for Joule to Work Correctly

When using custom roles with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, the role definition plays a critical role in determining what Joule can see, understand, and execute. Unlike traditional Fiori usage, Joule depends heavily on Launchpad content, semantic navigation, and backend OData access.

Below are the three key aspects you must consider while designing a custom role.

When creating a custom role, it is essential to ensure that it contains the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs. You can check this SAP Note for the required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

To verify this, you should always check the business catalogs that are assigned to your custom role. Business catalogs define which applications, semantic objects, and target mappings are available to the user - and these are what Joule relies on for navigation and execution.

For example, in this scenario, I created a single custom role by reusing a standard SAP business catalog that already contains all Purchase Order related semantic objects and Fiori app IDs.

 

By including this required semantic objects and Fiori app IDs in the custom role, Joule can correctly:

  • Resolve Purchase Order related intents
  • Navigate using the appropriate semantic object and action
  • Launch the correct Fiori applications without additional configuration

If you plan to use a Master Role and Derived Role approach, you can create the master role in the same way as described above, ensuring it contains all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app IDs.

Once the master role is created, you can then derive one or more derived roles from it. The derived roles inherit all the authorization content from the master role, while allowing you to maintain organizational-level restrictions if required.

I have also created a derived role from the master role, as shown in the screenshot below. The derived role inherits all the required business catalogs, semantic objects, and Fiori app mappings from the master role, ensuring consistent access behavior for Joule while allowing role assignment at the user level.

2️. How to Perform Content Exposure for Custom Roles

🔹V2 Content Exposure (Recommended)

If you are on SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition 2023 FPS01 or higher, you must expose your content using Content Exposure Version 2 (V2).

Before exposing content, ensure the following prerequisites are in place.

🔹Activate Required ICF Services

Make sure the following ICF service is active:

  • /sap/bc/http

You can verify and activate this using transaction SICF.

🔹Maintain Design-Time Destination in SAP BTP

In SAP BTP, the design-time destination must include the following service endpoint URL:

<host>/sap/bc/http/ui2/flp_content_exposure/entities

This endpoint is required for SAP Build Work Zone to read exposed content from S/4HANA.

🔹Activate HTTP Service via UCON

Since this is an HTTP-based service, it may need explicit activation.

  • Use transaction UCON_HTTP_SERVICES
  • Activate the service:
  • /UI2/FLP_CONTENT_EXPOSURE

This step is mandatory if the service is restricted by UCON.

🔹Required Authorization Roles

Ensure the following roles are assigned:

  • Administrator Role
    The administrator must have SAP Fiori Launchpad administration authorizations to expose content to SAP BTP.
  • SAP_FLP_EXP_USER
    Assign this role to the technical user used by SAP Build Work Zone.
    This role allows the user to read and consume exposed content.

🔹Which Roles Should Be Exposed?

To expose roles, use transaction:

/UI2/CDM3_EXP_SCOPE

Perform the following steps:

  1. Choose Exposure Version = Version 2
  2. Select roles under Areas
    • All selected roles across areas will be exposed
    • You can expose individual roles or group multiple roles under one area

Role Exposure Rules

  • Custom Single Role
    → Directly expose the custom role
  • Master & Derived Role Model
    → Expose the Master Role only
    (Derived roles cannot be exposed independently)
  • Alternative Approach
    If you do not want to expose the master role:
    • Create a Composite Role
    • Add the required derived roles
    • Expose the composite role

This approach provides flexibility while keeping role design clean.

🔹Verification Steps to Ensure Joule Can Consume the Content

Once the content exposure is completed:

  1. Go to SAP Build Work Zone
  2. Perform a content refresh / update

  3. Verify that:
    • Exposed apps are visible
    • Semantic navigation works
    • Apps can be launched from Work Zone

If the content is visible and accessible in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume and use the exposed content correctly.

3️. How to Set Up Identity Provisioning (IPS) to Test Custom Roles

Finally, to validate custom roles with Joule, you must configure the Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) job so that users and roles from SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition are provisioned correctly to SAP Build Work Zone.

In most productive systems, executing a full IPS job can take a significant amount of time, as it processes all users and all roles available in the source S/4HANA PCE system. For testing and validation purposes, it is recommended to limit the scope of provisioning using filters.

🔹Why Use Filters in IPS?

By applying filters, you can:

  • Provision only specific test users
  • Provision only relevant custom roles
  • Reduce job execution time

🔹Recommended IPS Filters for Testing

In the IPS source system configuration, add the following filters.

Role Filter

Use this filter to provision only the required custom roles.

abap.role.name.filter = (?i)^(ROLE1|ROLE2|ROLE3).*

🔹This filter:

  • Is case-insensitive ((?i))
  • Provisions only roles matching the specified role names

If you are using a Master and Derived Role model and assign derived roles to users, then you must maintain only the derived roles in this filter. Master roles should not be included unless they are directly assigned to users.

User Filter

Use this filter to provision only the test users.

abap.user.name.filter = ^(USER1|USER2|USER3).*

🔹Execute and Validate the IPS Job

After maintaining the filters:

  1. Run the IPS job
  2. Monitor the job status for errors
  3. Verify in SAP Build Work Zone that:
    • Test users are provisioned
    • Correct roles are assigned

  4. Log in as a test user and validate Joule behavior

If the users and roles are visible and correctly assigned in SAP Build Work Zone, Joule will be able to consume the exposed content and execute actions as expected.

entry.title: Legal Change - YATIRIMTESVIK scenario support through Extensibility in DRC Türkiye
entry.content:
This blog post introduces a guide on how to implement the new legal requirement released by GIB (GELİR İDARESİ BAŞKANLIĞI) for invoices issued under a valid Investment Incentive Certificate (Yatırım Teşvik Belgesi – YTB) through Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.


Background 
We have already published a Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud on how S/4HANA Public Cloud customers can leverage developer extensibility to modify content of XMLs produced during electronic invoice submissions, pertaining to specific business and legal requirements.

Note for: SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments: 

In SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and ECC environments, the exact same process exists through extensibility, however the BAdi implementation would have to be done for EDOC_ADAPTOR instead of EDOC_ADAPTOR_CLOUD.

What’s New? 
GIB has published a legal requirement pertaining to invoices issued under valid Investment Incentive Certificate which impacts a few companies on 21st November, 2025. In this blog we would aim to address the requirement through the learnings of the previous blog highlighted in the background.

What’s the technical specifications of the requirement? 
Currently system does not automatically determine whether a billing or finance document is YTB-related or not. The customer must explicitly indicate that the invoice belongs to a YTB investment project and provide the necessary values. As part of the legal requirement authority following is an easy requirement with an UBL (Universal Business Language, an ISO standard XML) representation:

  • New Profile IDs
    • YATIRIMTESVIK – for eInvoicing scenarios 
    • EARSIVFATURA – for eArchive scenarios 
  • New Invoice Type Codes under each invoicing scenarios
    • YATIRIMTESVIK – for eInvoicing scenarios.
      • SATIS – Sales invoices
      • ISTISNA – Exception invoices
      • IADE – Refund or Return invoices
    • EARSIVFATURA – for eArchive scenarios
      • YTBSATIS – consumer/eArchive sales invoice 
      • YTBISTISNA – consumer/eArchive exception invoices
      • YTBIADE – consumer/eArchive refund/return invoices
  • Mapping of new identification tag - ContractDocumentReference 
    • ID field should be the filled up with the incentive certificate number
      • schemeID of this would be "YTBNO"
    • IssueDate should be filled up with the investment certificate date in DD/MM/YYYY format 
  • Adjustments to existing tag - TaxTotal 
    • The waived VAT amount should be shown in XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxAmount only if profileID is YATIRIMTESVIK with invoice type value is ISTISNA, or profileID is EARSIVFATURA with invoice type value is YTBISTISNA.
    • Reason codes similar to tax exemption reason codes have been introduced as part of the technical structure from GIB available at their website. These reason codes have to be filled in XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxCategory/TaxExemptionReasonCode.
    • Subsequently new reason code descriptions have also been introduced as part of the technical structure which should go in the XPath TaxTotal/TaxSubtotal/TaxCategory/TaxExemptionReason corresponding the reason code filled in above step.
  • Adjustments to existing tag - InvoiceLine 
    • For YTB related scenarios the XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/CommodityClassification/ItemClassificationCode should be filled with 01, 02, 03, or 04 in case of the scenario of profile ID of YATIRIMTESVIK/EARSIVFATURA.
    • In case the ItemClassificationCode is 01 (Machine Equipment), and reason code in TaxExemptionReason is 308 as per the legal requirement, then
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/Name should be filled with machin name
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/ItemInstance/Name should be filled with Machine ID.
      • XPath tag InvoiceLine/Item/ItemInstance/ProductTraceID should be filled with the Machine Sequence Number/Equivalent details

How does a sample code looks like using Developer Extensibility?

The prerequisites, roles and BAdI Enhancement Implementation names have already been mentioned in our previous blog (details - Developer Extensibility for Document and Reporting Compliance Türkiye in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ).

Let's illustrate how this can be tailored to suit the above legal requirement.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS:
      <lfs_cs_doc_data>      TYPE edo_tr_inv_ubl_format_req,
      <fs_invoice_tab>       TYPE edo_tr_e_doc_turkey_invoic_tab,
      <fs_invoice_el>        TYPE edo_tr_e_doc_turkey_invoice_el,
      <fs_payment_means_tab> TYPE edo_tr_payment_means_tab,
      <fs_add_doc_ref>       TYPE edo_tr_additional_document_tab.

    ASSIGN COMPONENT 'DOC_DATA' OF STRUCTURE cs_output_data TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_data>).
    IF <lv_data> IS ASSIGNED.
      IF iv_edoc_type = 'TR_BINV'. "Turkey Basic eInvoice
        IF iv_interface_id NE 'TR_GETSTATUS_REQ'.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT 'PARAMETERS' OF STRUCTURE cs_output_data TO <lv_data>.
          IF <lv_data> IS ASSIGNED.
            ASSIGN cs_output_data TO <lfs_cs_doc_data>.
            IF <lfs_cs_doc_data> IS ASSIGNED.
              ASSIGN <lfs_cs_doc_data>-parameters-package-elements TO <fs_invoice_tab>.
              IF <fs_invoice_tab> IS ASSIGNED.
                LOOP AT <fs_invoice_tab> ASSIGNING <fs_invoice_el>.
* This is just a sample implementation, you can decide on the conditional assignment based on your business needs.
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-profile_id-base-base-content = 'YATIRIMTESVIK'.
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-invoice_type_code-base-base-content = 'SATIS'.
" Filling up ContractDocumentReference
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-contract_document_reference =
                    VALUE #( ( id-base-base-content = '1234567890'
                               id-base-base-scheme_id = 'YTBNO'
                               issue_date-base-content = '19990912' ) ).
" Filling up TaxTotal
                  <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-tax_total =
                    VALUE #( ( tax_subtotal =
                    VALUE #( ( tax_amount-base-content = '123.40'
                               tax_amount-base-currency_id = 'TRY'
                               tax_category-tax_exemption_reason_code-base-base-content = '308'
                               tax_category-tax_exemption_reason-base-base-content = 'Delivery of Investment Goods under Incentive Scheme 13/d' ) ) ) ).
" Filling up InvoiceLine
                  LOOP AT <fs_invoice_el>-element_list-invoice-invoice_line ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_invoice_line>).
                    <lfs_invoice_line>-item-commodity_classification = VALUE #( ( item_classification_code-base-base-content = '01' ) ).
                    READ TABLE <lfs_invoice_line>-item-commodity_classification ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<lfs_comm_class>)
                      WITH KEY item_classification_code-base-base-content = '01'.
                    IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
                      <lfs_invoice_line>-item-name-base-base-content = 'Machine Name'.
                      <lfs_invoice_line>-item-item_instance = VALUE #( ( serial_id-base-base-content = '9999999999'
                                                                         product_trace_id-base-base-content = '7878787878787878' ) ).
                    ENDIF.
                  ENDLOOP.
                ENDLOOP.
              ENDIF.
            ENDIF.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.

 

Spoiler
Disclaimer - This is just a sample code; actual business conditions are not depicted through this.

Result: 

When you display the XML file of the electronic document in the eDocument Cockpit (EDOC_COCKPIT) corresponding to the above invoicing scenario, you will see that the mentioned tags populated. Please note that based on actual submission of this document to authorized service provider, error handling and troubleshooting can be tackled.

Conclusion 
With recent enhancements to the Türkiye Document and Reporting Compliance solution, SAP has made it significantly easier to cater to targeted and industry specific legal requirements in electronic document outputs. 

This improvement gives you more flexibility and helps ensure compliance with Türkiye’s legal requirements. This blog is the first of the many blogs coming up to demonstrate legal requirements in an easy consumable way
